title: Permabanned for changing game.cfg even though Riot has said it's allowed.
body:
Hi, I'm GGS Sokeri.

I got permanently banned and after 31 days(!) I got a response: it was for (quote from Riot ticket response): "directly modifying the League of Legends game files, which is a ToU violation and punishable with a permanent suspension".

The only changes to "game files" were to a configuration file called game.cfg located somewhere in the LoL folders. I literally got permabanned just for changing one number.

Before touching anything I even researched if modifying "game.cfg" was allowed. I found numerous Riot employee and "Wrenchman" posts that said it's allowed or even instructed people to change the exact settings I was changing. Links are in the bottom of this post.

So the reason for the suspension was changing the resolution to get different aspect ratios (see 4:3, 16:9, 21:9 etc.). What this does is change the field of view. However, League of Legends natively supports ultrawide resolutions so buying a 21:9 monitor has the same effect. What changing game.cfg did was emulate this on a 16:9 screen. Here's what it looks like and how Riot themselves provide settings for ultrawide screens: http://imgur.com/a/FwIkY. 

Why should players have to buy a 21:9 monitor if they can have the same effect for free?


What do you guys think about this?

TL;DR: Changed screen resolution from LoL configuration file, permaban received even though Riot has said multiple times that it's allowed.

> [{quoted}](name=GGS Sokeri,realm=EUW,application-id=ZGEFLEUQ,discussion-id=XhXwwb0f,comment-id=00000000,timestamp=2016-01-05T22:23:47.827+0000)

I agree that it would be unacceptable for Riot to say one thing and do another, but when considering the fact that you are using information from when Riot was first becoming a company the line becomes far more blurry.  It's not entirely reasonable to expect that comments Riot made half a decade ago should still be valid today, and most of those comments are meant to fix problems rather than allow players to give themselves an advantage.

---

I can't speak to Riot's perspective here, but as an impartial observer I feel like this is a situation where improper information was used to achieve a result that falls under giving an advantage.  That being said, I also see your point, where you are essentially utilizing a different monitor spec emulated within your own.

This is an interesting case.

I'd argue that the "advantage" here is of negligible quality since it basically boils down to personal preference. If *any* player can capitalize on that resolution setting's "advantage" over the other resolutions by simply having a monitor of the appropriate size, then *every* player should have equal access to that resolution setting. What is unfair is saying you *can't* give yourself the resolution you prefer when it is an openly accessible change that is available to certain players for absolutely no reason other than their personal monitor.

I honestly feel like this is toeing the line a bit, because you're obviously doing it to gain more screen real estate than other players. At the same time, you have a fair point about the 21:9 monitor. Feel like it could go either way.

I fully agree it's toeing the line in this case, but at the same time, I've had to modify the config files in order to get my chat back when a bug placed it completely off the screen. 

According to the ToU, I've done something "*expressly prohibited by law and may result in severe civil and criminal penalties*" (ToU wording) by modifying the X and Y location of where the chat box was drawn. Both myself and the OP did something that was "*Modify[ing] or cause to be modified any files that are part of the Software in any way not expressly authorized by Riot Games*" (EULA wording) by changing the config files by hand rather than using the Game UI to do so.

I'm not fishing for a permaban myself, by any means, but I think it still raises a question for how fickle EULA or ToU enforcement could be.
